Full Information by Exponential Smoothing

Source: R/full_information.R
smoothing.Rd

Exponential smoothing twists probabilities by giving relatively more weight to recent observations at an exponential rate.

smoothing(x, lambda)

# S3 method for default
smoothing(x, lambda)

# S3 method for numeric
smoothing(x, lambda)

# S3 method for matrix
smoothing(x, lambda)

# S3 method for ts
smoothing(x, lambda)

# S3 method for xts
smoothing(x, lambda)

# S3 method for data.frame
smoothing(x, lambda)

# S3 method for tbl
smoothing(x, lambda)

Arguments

x

The risk-drivers.
lambda

A number with the decay parameter that generated the half-life.

Value

A tibble with the new probabilities distribution.

Details

The half-life is computed as:

HL = log(2) / lambda.

For example: log(2) / 0.0166 is approximately 42. So, a parameter lambda of 0.0166 can be associated with a half-life of two-months.

See also

crisp kernel_normal half_life

Examples

library(ggplot2)

# long half_life
long_hl <- smoothing(EuStockMarkets, 0.001)
long_hl

#> # Fully-Flexible Probability 
#> # A tibble: 1,860 x 2
#>    .rowid       .p
#>     <int>    <dbl>
#>  1      1 0.000184
#>  2      2 0.000185
#>  3      3 0.000185
#>  4      4 0.000185
#>  5      5 0.000185
#>  6      6 0.000185
#>  7      7 0.000186
#>  8      8 0.000186
#>  9      9 0.000186
#> 10     10 0.000186
#> # … with 1,850 more rows

ggplot(long_hl, aes(x = .rowid, y = .p, color = .p)) +
  geom_line(show.legend = FALSE) +
  scale_color_viridis_c()


# short half_life
short_hl <- smoothing(EuStockMarkets, 0.015)
ggplot(short_hl, aes(x = .rowid, y = .p, color = .p)) +
  geom_line(show.legend = FALSE) +
  scale_color_viridis_c()
